by Jon Stempel
Following the lead of the Committee on Freedom of Expression, which issued its report last
week, a second Universityformed committee has begun
evaluating
potentially
troublesome issues at the
Homewood campus.
University President Steven
Muller has charged the committee, called the Task Force on the
Human Climate at Homewood, to
assess and make recommendations for the "resolution of

specific issues, and steps to
elevate the campus spirit."
Jakie Hall, vice president for
institutional relations, chairs the
committee, which held its first
meeting yesterday. "It was appointed for the need to be responsive to changing times, changing
needs, changing issues, and to
come up with ways to deal with
these changes," he said of the
committee.
Along the issues the committee
will consider are the following:
academic dishonesty, alcohol and
drugs, campus security and the

role and conduct of security personnel, distrust of administration,
faculty-student relations, the
fraternity system, the status of
women, the status of minorities,
and student housing and dining.
Muller's main goal, stated in a
memorandum to Hall, is "to
achieve a campus climate in
which these and other issues can
be addressed in a spirit of mutual
respect, tolerance, civility,
cooperation,
and
open
communication."

"I always liked writing, but I
realized that it would take less
time to draw a cartoon than write
an article," explained nationallyknown cartoonist Sidney Harris
yesterday in his Wednesday Noon
Series lecture, "What's So Funny About Science?: A Cartoonist's View."
Harris, who began cartooning
over twenty-five years ago, has
had his works appear in American
Scientist, Playboy, The New
Yorker, Punch, and The Johns
Hopkins Magazine. He has also
written several books including
What's So Funny About Science.
His works have been on display
at the Smithsonian Museum of
Science, and can be seen now at
the Maryland Science Center.
Harris began the lecture by
showing a variety of his cartoons,
supplementing them with anecdotes. Many of his cartoons are
about science. In one, a man falling from a building recites the
formula for velocity and keeps
falling, then says the formula for
lift and is lifted upward.
In another, two scientists are
talking. "Unfortunately this lab
is funded only by as much gold
as we can make from bismuth,"
says one. Harris occasionally gets
his ideas from real life. In this
case, Harris was inspired by a
quotation from a scientist who
said, "We spend more time getting grants than doing research."
Harris also showed some of his
cartoons from Playboy, One
featured a well-built college
woman with a scarlet letter A on
her chest, resembling a varsity
letter. She passes two guys and
one says, "I think Karen's letter
is for a real extracurricular
activity."
In some copies of Playboy, the
letter came out in green and blue,
ruining the joke.
Harris received a few letters
concerning his cartoon of a
nuclear power plant with the caption, "Closed due to radiation

leak. Will be open in 70,000
years." An offended nuclear
scientist wrote Harris, complaining that the cartoon misinformed
people and scared them. "It
amazes me how suddenly people
take things so seriously it offends
them," said Harris.
In the second part of the lecture, Harris opened the floor for
questions, during which he
described the way he works, saying "The ideas are the essential
thing, the pictures come second."
He added, "I liked writing, but
I had little aptitude for drawing.
I don't think of the characters as
being essential in the cartoons. I
guess I hit stereotypes."
The day after he gets the ideas,
Harris thinks about them to pick
the ones to illustrate. Looking
back at old captions gives Harris

the chance to choose the ones to
illustrate. "It gives me something
to do tomorrow," he said.
Once he begins drawing, each
picture takes less than an hour to
complete. He said he can draw
several in one day. He spoke of
his difficulties in getting over the
obstacles of going to the bank, the
grocery store, and eating lunch.
Generally, he creates his ideas
in a systematic way for a whole
day. He goes through newspapers
for ideas, and through science
magazines to keep his scientific
knowledge.
"Ideas don't usually just come
to me," he said, "I'm generally
not in the mood [to begin working] but I do it anyway. I don't
generally wait for inspiration,
because this is a full-time job."

University Opens Foreign Language Center
Institute in D.C. to Investigate Possible Modes of Instruction
By Elizabeth Harrigan
National
The
Foreign
Language Center, the University's new research institute and
component of the School of Advanced International Studies in
Washington D.C., will attempt to
bring "a more focused approach
to foreign language pedagogy,"
said A. Ronald Walton, deputy
director of the center.
According to Walton, the
center is funded by the Ford
Foundation, the Exxon Foundation, and the Pew Memorial
Trust. It is headed by Richard
Lambert, a
comparative
sociology professor from the
University of Pennsylvania, who
for many years has been involved in language study.
The center, said Walton, grew

out of the desire to have a national
place where "language as
language" could be studied.
"Other countries have foreign
language policies," said Walton,
"but the U.S. problem is that
there is no clear choice as to a second language."
Walton said that Americans
might, from their heritage, be
drawn to the languages of Northern Europe. "However, those
are not necessarily the languages
of the future." said Walton.
"Japanese, Chinese, and the
African languages are becoming
increasingly important."
On the other hand, Walton emphasized that French is certainly
important in Africa, and Spanish
is useful in this country as well
as in Latin America, with whom
the U.S. does a great deal of

trade

Walton said that there is lack of
empiricism in language teaching.
The goals for the center involve
investigating "how it might be
possible to better learn language
skills on the college level," said
Walton, but also include studying
language teaching on the secondary and high school levels.
The center will offer what
Walton termed "experimental
learning." While actual courses
will not be taught, people will be
invited to come to the center and
be observed while they learn.
"We plan to focus on the
learner, and see where teaching
fits in," said Walton. "New
technology like video discs and
input devices are helpful, but not
efficient in the classroom. There
the emphasis is on the unique ex-

perience between teacher and student of conversational practice."
Walton said that there are three
primary sectors where language
is being taught in the U.S.: in
academia, in proprietary schools
such as Berlitz, and in the government. "We hope to get a dialogue
going between all three," said
Walton, "because each has
something to offer the other."
Walton said, "We plan to
develop a network of people
across the country, in government
as well as the private sector" to
conduct the center's studies.
"We'll ask that research papers
which have obvious relevance to
language instruction and follow
the center's guidelines be submitted," said Walton, "and with
task forces of scholars across the
country, we can see where

research is most needed."
Walton said that the center,
which is still in its early stages,
will be fully operational by this
summer. It will occupy one floor
of a newly acquired Hopkins
building on Massachusetts
Avenue.
Already, the center has, with
the Arab Language Department
of SAIS, co-sponsored a conference that focused on less commonly taught languages.
"Scholars of all the languages
were in agreement in that their
teaching needs were very
.similar," said Walton, "It was a
great success."
Ralph B. Ginsberg of the
University of Pennsylvania and
Walton will serve as deputy
directors of the language center.

the Rose Travelling Scholarship, enabling a Johns
Hopkins student who has not
yet received a BA to spend the
summer pursuing a project for
which travel to Europe is particularly important.
The project need not involve
formal study -in an academic
institution; it may involve
viewing objects in museums or
attending the theatre, or faceto-face interviews, as well as,
or instead of, library work. In
previous years, award recipients have gone to Vienna to
study German literary
criticism with original
sources, to the English countryside to examine the
geographical setting of
Thomas Hardy's novels, and
to London to work on women
writers in the British Museum.
It would be equally appropriate to use the opportunity to interview politicians, or
observe how doctors work
within the context of a publicly financed and regulated
health system.
Applicants are free to propose whatever they think
would contribute best to their
education, normally in the
period between the junior and
senior years. The award is not
intended for language study; a
candidate should show

whatever foreign-language
competence is sufficient for
the project.
The value of the award is up
to $2,000 for travel and living
expenses, as appropriate.
Preference will be given to
candidates who have not lived
in Europe, and persons who
have had a year of study in
Europe will normally not be
eligible. The award is made
possible by a gift from Richard
Rose, BA '53, Writing
Seminars, who went from
Hopkins to study in London.
A paper is required for submission at the end of the study
period; it may be submitted for
class credit, or take another
form, e.g. a set of photographs
or poems, as appropriate to the
project.
Anyone wishing further information should call Dean
Matthew Crenson, Associate
Dean of Arts and Sciences
(338-8215).
The deadline for applications is Friday, March 20.
Candidates should submit a
project description of three or
four pages with a brief vita and
have a faculty sponsor
separately send a letter of
evaluation. Material should be
sent to the Associate Dean,
School of Arts and Sciences,
Merryman 141. Decisions will
he announced in mid-April.

The End of an Era
This week marked the end of an era
at Homewood.
After weathering months of abuse
throwers,
from
cinder-block
firebombers, security demolition teams,
a bulldozer, and unsympathetic passersby, the Coalition for a Free South Africa
protest shanties finally succumbed to
Nature.
During Monday's fierce gales, the
shanties tumbled down. Coalition
members later removed the debris of the
most provocative structures ever erected
at Hopkins.
It is certainly a credit to the community that the shanties met their demise
under the onslaught of Nature rather
than at the hands of men.
Beyond the immediate political
significance of the shanties in the debate
over divestment, the structures came to
symbolize the University's commitment
to freedom of expression.
Both the shanties and those who built
them endured considerable abuse from
many sides in defending the right to
freedom of expression, but they were
able to withstand the rough treatment
and prevail. For that, all members of the

Hopkins community should be proud.
Now the shanty era has come to a
peaceful end. While the Coalition has
not yet achieved all of its goals, it has
won the most important battle here at
Hopkins—the battle for freedom of
expression.
It's time now to move forward and to
leave the shanties behind as symbols of
the victory for freedom of expression.
To reconstruct the shanties would be
to dilute their symbolic significance by
making them much too mundane. The
Coalition would do well instead to expand its symbolic repertoire in keeping
with its expanding interest in social injustice here in Baltimore and abroad.
Peaceful protests for social change
should always be provocative, creative
and unpredictable. Clinging to past
glories and past symbols is almost a sure
recipe for descent into obscurity.
We hope that the Coalition will
carefully reconsider its rumored plans
for the construction of new shanties.
The Coalition needs a new symbol and
a new rallying cry, not a return to the
days of last year.

Valentine Vacuum
So it's Friday. Tommorow is Cupid's
Christmas. You've checked the Valentine Personals and no amorous message
for you appeared. There's no Circle K
carnation peeking out of your mailbox
and no chocolates in your little brown
lunch bag. Even ol' QM has a date.
Don't despair! You're a healthy, sensual young adult, in the always romantically fruitful college environment. Go
to a dance, a theater, a bar...but wait!
Don't forget that you are at Hopkins,
a place known for romance as much as
Siberia's renowned for suntanning.
True, love is still a four-letter word, only here we spell it 0-R-G-0. Our loves

are not listed in little books or written
on our palms in indelible ink; the names
of our beaux and belles are typed neatly (along with the regular, weekly dates
of our torrid trysts) in lascivious little
packets called syllabi.
So spend Saturday with Solomon's
(over candlelight of course). Have a
menage a trois (Descartes and Locke)
on Sunday.
And come Monday, when classes are
suspended,(and provided your're not
past your "biological peak") you can
do it all over again. You won't be alone.
Love at Homewood?? Hey Cupid...Bah
Humbug!!

Ending a Post-Vacation
Hiatus
Congratulations at last to the Student
Council. After a post-vacation hiatus,
our undergraduate representative
organization finally met for a substantive discussion (with many members actually attending).
We couldn't be more pleased.
The principle topic of discussion at
Wednesday's meeting was a Coalitionsponsored plan to hold a presentation on
the issue of Baltimore's homeless.
Specifically, the presentation would examine the plight of the homeless in the
vicinity of Hopkins (both in East
Baltimore and Charles Village) and
what Hopkins can do to improve their
lot.
Later Council briefly discussed the
preliminary report of the Committee for

Freedom of Expression (published in its
entirety here on these pages last week).
The sudden shift in Council's attention away from media analysis toward
issues of concern to the student body
and the community at large is commendable. We hope that it will mark the
beginning of a trend toward more meaningful debates in upcoming weeks.
After all, Council's responsibilities to
its constituency don't end with the selection of committee chairmen, the criticizing of critics, and the planning of parties. On the contrary, Council can set
and should set a lead in tackling important problems extending throughout
Hopkins and its environs.
This week, Council seems to have
started in the right direction.

looking around at all the career
materials, catalogues, and
volumes covering the office
walls. "I need to be placed."
She paged through her
notebook, pencil poised in hand.
"Are you a Pre-Medical school
student or engineer?" she asked with a ready-to-help-you
smile.
"Neither," I said. "I need a
job."
"A JOB?" she asked in horror, smile disappearing. "Trust
me, you don't want a job. Why
don't you take some of these
pamphlets about graduate
school, read them at your
leisure and get back to us." She

handed me a 4-inch stack of
official-looking papers and
booklets. "What were your
scores on the GRE's?" she
asked.
"I didn't take GRE's," I
said. "I have absolutely no use
for GRE's."
She pretended not to hear
that. "Let's see . . . You can take
them next month, and while
you're there, you should take
the LSAT's, GMAT's, the
NKAP's—parts one thru five,
the MSLAT's, the RBAT's, the
FTAP's, the JWAP's, and even
the MCAT's,just to be a wellrounded Hopkins graduate."
She penciled me in for six
weekends during March. "That
will be eighteen-thousand, four
hundred dollars please. You can
pay in cash or we'll tack it on
to your tuition bill." She looked past me. "NEXT."
"I DON'T WANT TO

TAKE GRE'S!" I protested in
a loud voice, tossing the pile of
materials onto her desk. "I just
want a job."
"A job?" her attention turned back to me. She shook her
head in confusion. "Huh?"
"A job." I repeated. -You
know, nine-to-five hours, weekly paycheck, respected training
program. A job. A career. Place
me."
"Place you?"

"You're in luck. Next Tuesday

two weeks, and Union Carbide

petitions circulated during various
lectures do not prove anything
beyond a doubt, because they
have high duplication rates and no
student ID listings or even Social

authenticity.

cheapest plan would be a closed
circuit carrier system available to
listeners in University buildings

concluded that it would cost at
least ten thousand dollars for installation and two thousand every

depreciation or inflation.

undergraduates and 1000 grad
students attending Hopkins, about
875 upperclassmen and grad
students, living off-campus in
University-owned housing, and
about 750 freshmen on campus.
This station will reach less than
half of the student body.

Well, I know there is plenty of
room in Baltimore for good colleg radio—for any good radio—
but the station under consideration will be AM! To avoid
overlap, programming will be of
necessarily limited appeal. As an
[November 211 editorial said, "It
is even more difficult to believe
that anyone would want to spend
countless hours broadcasting to a
handful of listeners at best."

admissions interns for the fall of 1987. We are looking for

prospective students and their parents. Students must be

ability to put high school students and their parents at
ease.

must be able to talk about Johns Hopkins in an informed

recruitment process and be comfortable interacting with
others.

A Future in Gene Therapy
By Ely Brown
The world of medicine and
science is filled with questions
and problems to which there may
or may not be answers. The
public has questions of their own
and for very obvious reasons it is
interested in what breakthroughs
or stumbling blocks are occurring in the field today. 'The
Public Interest in Science" is a
five-part series that is being
presented here at Johns Hopkins
University and strives to inform
people from the community about
current topics in the scientific
field.
The first of the lectures was
presented Wednesday, February
4 in Mudd Lecture Hall at 8 p.m.
The topic was "Genetic
Engineering and Gene Therapy"
and speeches were given by
Theodore Friedman, MD, and
LeRoy Walters. The lecture
covered the technical aspects as
well as the ethical ones which can
be intensely controversial when
discussing this touchy subject.
Genetic engineering and gene
therapy theoretically can be used
by doctors and scientists in four
distinct ways. The first is in the
treatment of diseases directly
upon the afflicted cells involved,
but it is possible to also use
genetic engineering on the germ
cells so as to prohibit the continuation of the disease through
reproduction. Another way is to
use genetic therapy in the
"enhancement of capabilities" or
characteristics of the person involved. Again, treatment can be
on the somatic or reproductive
cells depending on the desired
outcome.
The main purpose of gene
therapy is to restore damaged
DNA in the cells of an organism
in order to bring about physical
changes in the body. By repairing a gene, one can correct the
proteins and enzymes that it pro-

duces and this will ultimately lead
to morphological changes in the
organism.
There are currently four techniques that are being explored by
scientists to "repair" the genes.
One way is to correct stagnant
genes by activating them with
drugs. Genetic errors are often
found in the order of the nucleic
acids that make up the DNA
strand, and therefore scientists
are trying to correct these errors
by either removing the incorrect
portion and replacing it with a
functional part or by inserting the
correct acids over the inoperative
ones and in essence "sewing
over" the error. These latter two
possible techniques seem to be
impossible to bring about, but the
final method, that of gene addition, seems to have significant
possibilities.
In gene addition, the main idea
is to insert a functional strand of
DNA into a nonfunctional one.
The major problem with the other
techniques is that the technology
for the necessary procedures does
not exist today. However, with
gene addition, scientists have
taken advantage of viruses as a
way to bring about the changes
needed in the DNA strand.
Viruses, by their very nature, add
their own DNA to our DNA in
our genes and this technique is
how they bring harm to the
organism. Scientists are trying to
create viruses that will carry the
correct DNA strand into the cell
and add it to the gene in order to
correct the problem. However,
stumbling blocks still exist in this
theory, the biggest being having
little or no control over the placement of the added strand.
There are well over 3000
known genetic disorders that
could theoretically be corrected
with gene therapy. Few people
have problems accepting this
idea, but the use of gene therapy
for enhancing or increasing

characteristics seems to raise
ethical questions. Increasing the
height of an extremely short person is fine, but what about increasing the height of a basketball
player so that he would have a
better chance of making the pros?
As with steroids today, gene
therapy in the future could cause
heated controversy in the athletic
world.
Competitiveness, destructiveness, and territoriality are all
characteristics that are present in
each and every human, and
although they may not be the
most positive ones we possess,
they are part of what defines
human nature, and do scientists
have the right to employ gene
therapy to "correct" us? Today,
gene therapy is for the most part
contained in the laboratory and
used on rats and other lab
animals. But, one day, gene
therapy may become part of our
everyday lives and when it does
many ethical questions will have
to be solved.
The public needs to be informed of the breakthroughs occurring in science today if they're expected to help solve these problems in the future. This lecture
series, presented by the Program
in Science and Writing in the
Writing Seminars and the Student
Council, aims to present the
public with just this type of information. Although two speakers
will be presented at each lecture,
it is not a debate, but rather a way
to present different facets of the
same topic to the public and to
allow them to make their own
judgments. Other topics include
human evolution, "The Descent
of Man" to be presented on
Wednesday, February 18;
"AIDS" on Wednesday, March
4; "Women in Science" on
Wednesday, April 1; and
"Science and Dissent in the
Soviet Union" on Wednesday,
April 15.

Science in Brief
Diagnosing Mental Illness in the
Elderly
Researchers at the Johns
Hopkins Medical Institutions
report that physicians are less
likely to diagnose and treat emotional and psychological disorders
that occur among the elderly than
those among people under 65. At
a time when the elderly population is growing and the costs of
administering health care is increasing, the researchers feel the
untreated psychological problems
are causing needless increases in
health care spending. Methods
such as having patients complete
a health questionnaire that has
been effective in detecting the
presence of mental illness can be
used to substantially increase the
physician's chances of diagnosing
and treating any problems found
in his elderly patients.
The researchers also found that
an elderly person with a mental
illness had the best chances of
receiving adequate care in the
primary health setting (usually in
the office of their private
physician).

Searching for a Treatment for
Osteoporosis
Physicians at the Johns
Hopkins Hospital are now conducting experiments to investigate
whether exercise will arrest or
alleviate the symptoms of
osteoporosis, a non-traumatic
bone disease marked by thinning

bones and increased susceptibility to breakage. The two-year
study is being conducted on
beagles to see if those on a
regimen of daily exercise will
undergo any increase in bone
mass. Preliminary studies have
shown that exercise in young
animals causes a 20 to 30 percent
increase in bone mass.
Beagles were chosen for the experiments because their skeleton
is reputedly very similar to a
human's in bone structure and
composition.

Hopkins Investigating Medical
Technology and Practice
In order to investigate new
cost-control and productivity
methods, the Johns Hopkins
Hospital has recently opened The
Johns Hopkins Program for
Medical Technology and Practice
Assessment. This office will be
looking for new technologies and
physician practice patterns that
are more cost-effective in order
to better use the limited funds of
the Hospital and to better help
government policy-makers make
better decisions on financing and
regulating health care.
Among the projects that the office will investigate are: the most
cost-effective use of radiological
dyes, cheaper and more successful treatments for heart attack
victims, and the effects of health
care payment plans on the
Hospital's finances.

Blue Swamps Swarthmore
Hoopsters Bounce Back And Win Again
by Danny Kofos
The men's varsity basketball
team broke a five game losing
streak Wednesday night, beating
Swarthmore 69-64 at the Newton
H. White Athletic Center. The
Jays had control of this one most
of the way, at one point leading
by 20. The score at the half was
in Hopkins' favor, 39-24. Frosh
Paul Heiss, whose tenacious
defense and strong rebounding
have given him a starting opportunity, sunk 7. Senior captain
Chris Wasson led all scorers with
a game-high 19, while Mike
Latimore dropped in 18 and added 9 rebounds. Joel Sieperski, a
6'8" frosh who has shown rapid
development under Coach
Nelson, helped the cause with 15

points.
The Blue Jays were not as fortunate in the beginning of the
week when they faced much
stronger opposition. Last Saturday, Hopkins faced Widener,
who holds first place in the MAC
Southeast Division and is ranked
No. 3 in Division III. Widener
(17-2, 7-0) acquired a 22 point
lead by the end of the half, 32-10.
The Jays scored a season-low 40
points in this contest with the final
being 56-40. Soph Jedan Phillips
led Hopkins with 13 and Chris
Wasson followed with 9.
Emory University which, along
with Hopkins, recently gained admission to the newly formed
University Athletic Association,
visited the Athletic Center for the
first time last Monday night.

Hopkins led this one by nine with
13:40 remaining. Paul Damm of
Emory scored seven consecutive
points cutting the lead to 62-60.
Latimore's bucket, with 8:29 left,
showed the Jays ahead 71-67.
Damm then sunk 3 in a row, including 2 three-point attempts.
The final was Emory 90, Hopkins
82. Damm led all scorers on this
night, dropping 28, 24 of which
were in the second half. Senior
Chris Wasson led the scoring attack for the Jays with 26, and
Jedan Phillips dropped 21.
The Jays go away this Saturday
to Widener, and come back home
Monday to play Ursinus at 8 p.m.
Wednesday night the Blue Jays
play their final home game this
season against Haverford at 8
p.m.

Hustling Jays Cover Spread
by Patrick Furey
Last November 24, the JV
basketball team travelled to Cecil
Community College for their
season opener. For many of the
players on the team, it was not
only the first game of the season,
it was the first organized basketball game they had ever played
in. Most of the Blue Jays didn't
know what to expect, and those
who did expected the worst.
Well, that's exactly what they
got, as Cecil slam-dunked their
way to a 107-37 victory. That's
right, Hopkins was defeated by
70 points.
The best part about losing your
opener by 70 is that things can only get better. Gradually, the Blue
Jays improved to the point where
they were competetive in just
about every game they played. A
mere two weeks after losing to
Cecil, Hopkins came within four
points of their first victory in two
years. The very next day, they
came even closer, dropping to
Penn State (Ogontz) by a score of
56-54. Despite this drastic turnaround, all they had to show for
their efforts on January 26 was an
0-6 record.
Finally, the Blue Jays shook the
monkey off of their backs on
January 27, as they defeated
Messiah. After that, Hopkins
demonstrated their improvement
by extremely tough playing in
losses to Navy and Howard Community College. By last Monday,
the JV team had shown that they
could play solid basketball. They
had proven to their coach and to
their "faithful few" fans that
what they lacked in talent, they
made up for with guts and hustle. They could finally walk away
from their season with a feeling
of great accomplishment, for they
had regained the pride that they
had lost on November 24. It
would seem that Hopkins had
nothing left to prove as they
entered their final game of the
season last Monday at Homewood. Their opponent, however,
was Cecil Community College.
Cecil once again dominated
with their quickness, using a fullcourt press and a great inside

game to crush the Jays 87-37. But
this game wasn't the same as the
November 24 thrashing. There
were no slam dunks, no three-onone breakaways, and no chuckles
from the Cecil bench. Though
Hopkins lost by 50, they walked
away with a victory. They outhustled the Seahawks, and made
Cecil work for every basket. The
Blue Jays showed more guts.
It's difficult to single out individuals for outstanding improvement, because everyone on
the team has come a long way.
Freshman Tim Coyle has become
a good inside player, grabbing rebounds with authority and drawing fouls in key situations. Brian
"Sheep" Tarver has coupled an
outstanding shot with great hustle.
Steve Blumenthal has become a
consistent scoring machine, rack-

ing up three-pointers with ease.
Mike Stern has developed into
one of the finest rebounders on
the team, simply by consistently
muscling himself into the "smart
spot."
It's no secret that most of the
JV team played their final game
in a Hopkins basketball uniform
last Monday night, because next
season will probably see a drastic
change in the quality of Hopkins
hoops. Coach Web Johnson did
a tremendous job molding the
Blue Jays into a competitive unit.
His team may not be the most
talented in the world, but you'd
hae to look pretty hard to find a
team with more guts than the
Hopkins JV basketball team.
They've come a long way since
November 24.

"I always liked writing, but I
realized that it would take less
time to draw a cartoon than write
an article," explained nationallyknown cartoonist Sidney Harris
yesterday in his Wednesday Noon
Series lecture, "What's So Funny About Science?: A Cartoonist's View."
Harris, who began cartooning
over twenty-five years ago, has
had his works appear in American
Scientist, Playboy, The New
Yorker, Punch, and The Johns
Hopkins Magazine. He has also
written several books including
What's So Funny About Science.
His works have been on display
at the Smithsonian Museum of
Science, and can be seen now at
the Maryland Science Center.
Harris began the lecture by
showing a variety of his cartoons,
supplementing them with anecdotes. Many of his cartoons are
about science. In one, a man falling from a building recites the
formula for velocity and keeps
falling, then says the formula for
lift and is lifted upward.
In another, two scientists are
talking. "Unfortunately this lab
is funded only by as much gold
as we can make from bismuth,"
says one. Harris occasionally gets
his ideas from real life. In this
case, Harris was inspired by a
quotation from a scientist who
said, "We spend more time getting grants than doing research."
Harris also showed some of his
cartoons from Playboy, One
featured a well-built college
woman with a scarlet letter A on
her chest, resembling a varsity
letter. She passes two guys and
one says, "I think Karen's letter
is for a real extracurricular
activity."
In some copies of Playboy, the
letter came out in green and blue,
ruining the joke.
Harris received a few letters
concerning his cartoon of a
nuclear power plant with the caption, "Closed due to radiation

leak. Will be open in 70,000
years." An offended nuclear
scientist wrote Harris, complaining that the cartoon misinformed
people and scared them. "It
amazes me how suddenly people
take things so seriously it offends
them," said Harris.
In the second part of the lecture, Harris opened the floor for
questions, during which he
described the way he works, saying "The ideas are the essential
thing, the pictures come second."
He added, "I liked writing, but
I had little aptitude for drawing.
I don't think of the characters as
being essential in the cartoons. I
guess I hit stereotypes."
The day after he gets the ideas,
Harris thinks about them to pick
the ones to illustrate. Looking
back at old captions gives Harris

the chance to choose the ones to
illustrate. "It gives me something
to do tomorrow," he said.
Once he begins drawing, each
picture takes less than an hour to
complete. He said he can draw
several in one day. He spoke of
his difficulties in getting over the
obstacles of going to the bank, the
grocery store, and eating lunch.
Generally, he creates his ideas
in a systematic way for a whole
day. He goes through newspapers
for ideas, and through science
magazines to keep his scientific
knowledge.
"Ideas don't usually just come
to me," he said, "I'm generally
not in the mood [to begin working] but I do it anyway. I don't
generally wait for inspiration,
because this is a full-time job."

University Opens Foreign Language Center
Institute in D.C. to Investigate Possible Modes of Instruction
By Elizabeth Harrigan
National
The
Foreign
Language Center, the University's new research institute and
component of the School of Advanced International Studies in
Washington D.C., will attempt to
bring "a more focused approach
to foreign language pedagogy,"
said A. Ronald Walton, deputy
director of the center.
According to Walton, the
center is funded by the Ford
Foundation, the Exxon Foundation, and the Pew Memorial
Trust. It is headed by Richard
Lambert, a
comparative
sociology professor from the
University of Pennsylvania, who
for many years has been involved in language study.
The center, said Walton, grew

out of the desire to have a national
place where "language as
language" could be studied.
"Other countries have foreign
language policies," said Walton,
"but the U.S. problem is that
there is no clear choice as to a second language."
Walton said that Americans
might, from their heritage, be
drawn to the languages of Northern Europe. "However, those
are not necessarily the languages
of the future." said Walton.
"Japanese, Chinese, and the
African languages are becoming
increasingly important."
On the other hand, Walton emphasized that French is certainly
important in Africa, and Spanish
is useful in this country as well
as in Latin America, with whom
the U.S. does a great deal of

trade

Walton said that there is lack of
empiricism in language teaching.
The goals for the center involve
investigating "how it might be
possible to better learn language
skills on the college level," said
Walton, but also include studying
language teaching on the secondary and high school levels.
The center will offer what
Walton termed "experimental
learning." While actual courses
will not be taught, people will be
invited to come to the center and
be observed while they learn.
"We plan to focus on the
learner, and see where teaching
fits in," said Walton. "New
technology like video discs and
input devices are helpful, but not
efficient in the classroom. There
the emphasis is on the unique ex-

perience between teacher and student of conversational practice."
Walton said that there are three
primary sectors where language
is being taught in the U.S.: in
academia, in proprietary schools
such as Berlitz, and in the government. "We hope to get a dialogue
going between all three," said
Walton, "because each has
something to offer the other."
Walton said, "We plan to
develop a network of people
across the country, in government
as well as the private sector" to
conduct the center's studies.
"We'll ask that research papers
which have obvious relevance to
language instruction and follow
the center's guidelines be submitted," said Walton, "and with
task forces of scholars across the
country, we can see where

research is most needed."
Walton said that the center,
which is still in its early stages,
will be fully operational by this
summer. It will occupy one floor
of a newly acquired Hopkins
building on Massachusetts
Avenue.
Already, the center has, with
the Arab Language Department
of SAIS, co-sponsored a conference that focused on less commonly taught languages.
"Scholars of all the languages
were in agreement in that their
teaching needs were very
.similar," said Walton, "It was a
great success."
Ralph B. Ginsberg of the
University of Pennsylvania and
Walton will serve as deputy
directors of the language center.

The End of an Era
This week marked the end of an era
at Homewood.
After weathering months of abuse
throwers,
from
cinder-block
firebombers, security demolition teams,
a bulldozer, and unsympathetic passersby, the Coalition for a Free South Africa
protest shanties finally succumbed to
Nature.
During Monday's fierce gales, the
shanties tumbled down. Coalition
members later removed the debris of the
most provocative structures ever erected
at Hopkins.
It is certainly a credit to the community that the shanties met their demise
under the onslaught of Nature rather
than at the hands of men.
Beyond the immediate political
significance of the shanties in the debate
over divestment, the structures came to
symbolize the University's commitment
to freedom of expression.
Both the shanties and those who built
them endured considerable abuse from
many sides in defending the right to
freedom of expression, but they were
able to withstand the rough treatment
and prevail. For that, all members of the

Hopkins community should be proud.
Now the shanty era has come to a
peaceful end. While the Coalition has
not yet achieved all of its goals, it has
won the most important battle here at
Hopkins—the battle for freedom of
expression.
It's time now to move forward and to
leave the shanties behind as symbols of
the victory for freedom of expression.
To reconstruct the shanties would be
to dilute their symbolic significance by
making them much too mundane. The
Coalition would do well instead to expand its symbolic repertoire in keeping
with its expanding interest in social injustice here in Baltimore and abroad.
Peaceful protests for social change
should always be provocative, creative
and unpredictable. Clinging to past
glories and past symbols is almost a sure
recipe for descent into obscurity.
We hope that the Coalition will
carefully reconsider its rumored plans
for the construction of new shanties.
The Coalition needs a new symbol and
a new rallying cry, not a return to the
days of last year.

Valentine Vacuum
So it's Friday. Tommorow is Cupid's
Christmas. You've checked the Valentine Personals and no amorous message
for you appeared. There's no Circle K
carnation peeking out of your mailbox
and no chocolates in your little brown
lunch bag. Even ol' QM has a date.
Don't despair! You're a healthy, sensual young adult, in the always romantically fruitful college environment. Go
to a dance, a theater, a bar...but wait!
Don't forget that you are at Hopkins,
a place known for romance as much as
Siberia's renowned for suntanning.
True, love is still a four-letter word, only here we spell it 0-R-G-0. Our loves

are not listed in little books or written
on our palms in indelible ink; the names
of our beaux and belles are typed neatly (along with the regular, weekly dates
of our torrid trysts) in lascivious little
packets called syllabi.
So spend Saturday with Solomon's
(over candlelight of course). Have a
menage a trois (Descartes and Locke)
on Sunday.
And come Monday, when classes are
suspended,(and provided your're not
past your "biological peak") you can
do it all over again. You won't be alone.
Love at Homewood?? Hey Cupid...Bah
Humbug!!

Ending a Post-Vacation
Hiatus
Congratulations at last to the Student
Council. After a post-vacation hiatus,
our undergraduate representative
organization finally met for a substantive discussion (with many members actually attending).
We couldn't be more pleased.
The principle topic of discussion at
Wednesday's meeting was a Coalitionsponsored plan to hold a presentation on
the issue of Baltimore's homeless.
Specifically, the presentation would examine the plight of the homeless in the
vicinity of Hopkins (both in East
Baltimore and Charles Village) and
what Hopkins can do to improve their
lot.
Later Council briefly discussed the
preliminary report of the Committee for

Freedom of Expression (published in its
entirety here on these pages last week).
The sudden shift in Council's attention away from media analysis toward
issues of concern to the student body
and the community at large is commendable. We hope that it will mark the
beginning of a trend toward more meaningful debates in upcoming weeks.
After all, Council's responsibilities to
its constituency don't end with the selection of committee chairmen, the criticizing of critics, and the planning of parties. On the contrary, Council can set
and should set a lead in tackling important problems extending throughout
Hopkins and its environs.
This week, Council seems to have
started in the right direction.

"Hello, may I help you?"
The attractive secretary greeted
me as I walked into the room.
"Yes, is this the PLACEMENT OFFICE?" I asked,
looking around at all the career
materials, catalogues, and
volumes covering the office
walls. "I need to be placed."
She paged through her
notebook, pencil poised in hand.
"Are you a Pre-Medical school
student or engineer?" she asked with a ready-to-help-you
smile.
"Neither," I said. "I need a
job."
"A JOB?" she asked in horror, smile disappearing. "Trust
me, you don't want a job. Why
don't you take some of these
pamphlets about graduate
school, read them at your
leisure and get back to us." She

handed me a 4-inch stack of
official-looking papers and
booklets. "What were your
scores on the GRE's?" she
asked.
"I didn't take GRE's," I
said. "I have absolutely no use
for GRE's."
She pretended not to hear
that. "Let's see . . . You can take
them next month, and while
you're there, you should take
the LSAT's, GMAT's, the
NKAP's—parts one thru five,
the MSLAT's, the RBAT's, the
FTAP's, the JWAP's, and even
the MCAT's,just to be a wellrounded Hopkins graduate."
She penciled me in for six
weekends during March. "That
will be eighteen-thousand, four
hundred dollars please. You can
pay in cash or we'll tack it on
to your tuition bill." She looked past me. "NEXT."
"I DON'T WANT TO

TAKE GRE'S!" I protested in
a loud voice, tossing the pile of
materials onto her desk. "I just
want a job."
"A job?" her attention turned back to me. She shook her
head in confusion. "Huh?"
"A job." I repeated. -You
know, nine-to-five hours, weekly paycheck, respected training
program. A job. A career. Place
me."
"Place you?"
•
"An interview."
The light dawned. "OH, an
interview," she smiled broadly.
"You're in luck. Next Tuesday
Westinghouse is coming to campus, DuPont's interviewing in
two weeks, and Union Carbide
will be interviewing soon after
that." She pointed to a list on
her desk. "Sign up here.
NEXT."

admissions interns for the fall of 1987. We are looking for
people-oriented students to assist in the recruitment process by conducting the traditional on-campus interview.

prospective students and their parents. Students must be
poised and mature and possess tact, diplomacy and the
ability to put high school students and their parents at
ease.

good standing and plan to graduate in May 1988. Interns
must be able to talk about Johns Hopkins in an informed
and positive way, have a desire to participate in the
recruitment process and be comfortable interacting with
others.
Interns will be responsible for conducting admissions interviews with prospective students and meeting their
parents and responding to their questions and concerns.

of each interview. This will involve three or four hour-long
interviews each week from September 21 through midDecember. These are paid positions.

will be on May 18 and 19, and August 31 and September

or her interest and listing two references, to Jerome D.
Schnydman, Director of Admissions. Both references must
be members of the Johns Hopkins community, preferably
one member of the faculty and one from the administration. Students should apply by March 16.

by Joseph Gergyes
Dr. Frank A. Oski of The
Johns Hopkins Medical Institutions presented the third talk in
the 1986-87 William Henry
Welch Lecture Series to an
overflow crowd in the Garrett
Room of the Eisenhower Library
last week. His talk, "Pediatrics:
The Only Medical Discipline with
a Future" dealt with a wide host
of issues that physicians and
public health officials in the U.S.
are dealing with, most prominently the high national infant
mortality rate and the medical
problems asssociated with the increasing amount of children being born in proverty.
Dr. Oski began his lecture
citing the great advances the U.S.
has made in the longevity of its
citizens. In 1900, according to
Oski, only 4% of the population
was over the age of 65 and this
percentage continued to grow to
reach a figure of 11% today. By
the year 2000, Oski expects that
number to be 13%, and be 2025,
senior citizens are expected to account for a full 20% of the

population. The lesser known
fact, however, is that the life expectancy of a 40-year old has not
increased much over the last century. A 40-year old in 1900 could
expect to live to 73, his counterpart today could expect to reach
77.
"Such figures show," said
Oski, "that the numbers reflect a
decrease in the number of immature deaths: the neonatal
(fatalities), the inherited diseases,
accidents, and infectious
diseases." Though Dr. Oski attributes the decrease in immature
deaths to improvements in nutrition, water quality, antibiotics,
and disease prevention, he maintains that the pediatrician was
often the guiding force behind
those improvements. The importance of good health care at an
early age was emphasized again
and again by Oski and finally
summarized in the statement,
"the future of American health is
in the hands of pediatricians."
Though health care in general
has improved in the United States
and Dr. Oski forsees a day when
the average life expectancy of

Americans at birth will be around
85, the problem of infant mortality is still a pressing one. Presently
the rate is 18.4 deaths per
100,000 births, not a very respectable number considering the extensiveness of our hospital and
medical system. Most industrialized nations including
nearly all of Europe have lower
rates. The most shocking statistic,
however, is that the infant mortality rate among certain groups
such as inner-city blacks is
astronomically high, a blight on
our medical system, according to
Dr. Oski.
The infant mortality rate among
blacks in Baltimore city now
stands at 59.5 deaths per
100,000, many times higher than
the rate for whites, and higher
than the rate of many developing
countries such as Costa Rica or
Panama. Dr. Oski cited alcohol
and drug abuse, poor food selection, and the highest teen
pregnancy rate in the nation as
reasons why Baltimore has the
fourth highest rate of infant mortality in the country.

A Future in Gene Therapy
By Ely Brown
The world of medicine and
science is filled with questions
and problems to which there may
or may not be answers. The
public has questions of their own
and for very obvious reasons it is
interested in what breakthroughs
or stumbling blocks are occurring in the field today. 'The
Public Interest in Science" is a
five-part series that is being
presented here at Johns Hopkins
University and strives to inform
people from the community about
current topics in the scientific
field.
The first of the lectures was
presented Wednesday, February
4 in Mudd Lecture Hall at 8 p.m.
The topic was "Genetic
Engineering and Gene Therapy"
and speeches were given by
Theodore Friedman, MD, and
LeRoy Walters. The lecture
covered the technical aspects as
well as the ethical ones which can
be intensely controversial when
discussing this touchy subject.
Genetic engineering and gene
therapy theoretically can be used
by doctors and scientists in four
distinct ways. The first is in the
treatment of diseases directly
upon the afflicted cells involved,
but it is possible to also use
genetic engineering on the germ
cells so as to prohibit the continuation of the disease through
reproduction. Another way is to
use genetic therapy in the
"enhancement of capabilities" or
characteristics of the person involved. Again, treatment can be
on the somatic or reproductive
cells depending on the desired
outcome.
The main purpose of gene
therapy is to restore damaged
DNA in the cells of an organism
in order to bring about physical
changes in the body. By repairing a gene, one can correct the
proteins and enzymes that it pro-

duces and this will ultimately lead
to morphological changes in the
organism.
There are currently four techniques that are being explored by
scientists to "repair" the genes.
One way is to correct stagnant
genes by activating them with
drugs. Genetic errors are often
found in the order of the nucleic
acids that make up the DNA
strand, and therefore scientists
are trying to correct these errors
by either removing the incorrect
portion and replacing it with a
functional part or by inserting the
correct acids over the inoperative
ones and in essence "sewing
over" the error. These latter two
possible techniques seem to be
impossible to bring about, but the
final method, that of gene addition, seems to have significant
possibilities.
In gene addition, the main idea
is to insert a functional strand of
DNA into a nonfunctional one.
The major problem with the other
techniques is that the technology
for the necessary procedures does
not exist today. However, with
gene addition, scientists have
taken advantage of viruses as a
way to bring about the changes
needed in the DNA strand.
Viruses, by their very nature, add
their own DNA to our DNA in
our genes and this technique is
how they bring harm to the
organism. Scientists are trying to
create viruses that will carry the
correct DNA strand into the cell
and add it to the gene in order to
correct the problem. However,
stumbling blocks still exist in this
theory, the biggest being having
little or no control over the placement of the added strand.
There are well over 3000
known genetic disorders that
could theoretically be corrected
with gene therapy. Few people
have problems accepting this
idea, but the use of gene therapy
for enhancing or increasing

characteristics seems to raise
ethical questions. Increasing the
height of an extremely short person is fine, but what about increasing the height of a basketball
player so that he would have a
better chance of making the pros?
As with steroids today, gene
therapy in the future could cause
heated controversy in the athletic
world.
Competitiveness, destructiveness, and territoriality are all
characteristics that are present in
each and every human, and
although they may not be the
most positive ones we possess,
they are part of what defines
human nature, and do scientists
have the right to employ gene
therapy to "correct" us? Today,
gene therapy is for the most part
contained in the laboratory and
used on rats and other lab
animals. But, one day, gene
therapy may become part of our
everyday lives and when it does
many ethical questions will have
to be solved.
The public needs to be informed of the breakthroughs occurring in science today if they're expected to help solve these problems in the future. This lecture
series, presented by the Program
in Science and Writing in the
Writing Seminars and the Student
Council, aims to present the
public with just this type of information. Although two speakers
will be presented at each lecture,
it is not a debate, but rather a way
to present different facets of the
same topic to the public and to
allow them to make their own
judgments. Other topics include
human evolution, "The Descent
of Man" to be presented on
Wednesday, February 18;
"AIDS" on Wednesday, March
4; "Women in Science" on
Wednesday, April 1; and
"Science and Dissent in the
Soviet Union" on Wednesday,
April 15.

Science in Brief
Diagnosing Mental Illness in the
Elderly
Researchers at the Johns
Hopkins Medical Institutions
report that physicians are less
likely to diagnose and treat emotional and psychological disorders
that occur among the elderly than
those among people under 65. At
a time when the elderly population is growing and the costs of
administering health care is increasing, the researchers feel the
untreated psychological problems
are causing needless increases in
health care spending. Methods
such as having patients complete
a health questionnaire that has
been effective in detecting the
presence of mental illness can be
used to substantially increase the
physician's chances of diagnosing
and treating any problems found
in his elderly patients.
The researchers also found that
an elderly person with a mental
illness had the best chances of
receiving adequate care in the
primary health setting (usually in
the office of their private
physician).

Searching for a Treatment for
Osteoporosis
Physicians at the Johns
Hopkins Hospital are now conducting experiments to investigate
whether exercise will arrest or
alleviate the symptoms of
osteoporosis, a non-traumatic
bone disease marked by thinning

bones and increased susceptibility to breakage. The two-year
study is being conducted on
beagles to see if those on a
regimen of daily exercise will
undergo any increase in bone
mass. Preliminary studies have
shown that exercise in young
animals causes a 20 to 30 percent
increase in bone mass.
Beagles were chosen for the experiments because their skeleton
is reputedly very similar to a
human's in bone structure and
composition.

Hopkins Investigating Medical
Technology and Practice
In order to investigate new
cost-control and productivity
methods, the Johns Hopkins
Hospital has recently opened The
Johns Hopkins Program for
Medical Technology and Practice
Assessment. This office will be
looking for new technologies and
physician practice patterns that
are more cost-effective in order
to better use the limited funds of
the Hospital and to better help
government policy-makers make
better decisions on financing and
regulating health care.
Among the projects that the office will investigate are: the most
cost-effective use of radiological
dyes, cheaper and more successful treatments for heart attack
victims, and the effects of health
care payment plans on the
Hospital's finances.

Blue Swamps Swarthmore
Hoopsters Bounce Back And Win Again
by Danny Kofos
The men's varsity basketball
team broke a five game losing
streak Wednesday night, beating
Swarthmore 69-64 at the Newton
H. White Athletic Center. The
Jays had control of this one most
of the way, at one point leading
by 20. The score at the half was
in Hopkins' favor, 39-24. Frosh
Paul Heiss, whose tenacious
defense and strong rebounding
have given him a starting opportunity, sunk 7. Senior captain
Chris Wasson led all scorers with
a game-high 19, while Mike
Latimore dropped in 18 and added 9 rebounds. Joel Sieperski, a
6'8" frosh who has shown rapid
development under Coach
Nelson, helped the cause with 15

points.
The Blue Jays were not as fortunate in the beginning of the
week when they faced much
stronger opposition. Last Saturday, Hopkins faced Widener,
who holds first place in the MAC
Southeast Division and is ranked
No. 3 in Division III. Widener
(17-2, 7-0) acquired a 22 point
lead by the end of the half, 32-10.
The Jays scored a season-low 40
points in this contest with the final
being 56-40. Soph Jedan Phillips
led Hopkins with 13 and Chris
Wasson followed with 9.
Emory University which, along
with Hopkins, recently gained admission to the newly formed
University Athletic Association,
visited the Athletic Center for the
first time last Monday night.

Hopkins led this one by nine with
13:40 remaining. Paul Damm of
Emory scored seven consecutive
points cutting the lead to 62-60.
Latimore's bucket, with 8:29 left,
showed the Jays ahead 71-67.
Damm then sunk 3 in a row, including 2 three-point attempts.
The final was Emory 90, Hopkins
82. Damm led all scorers on this
night, dropping 28, 24 of which
were in the second half. Senior
Chris Wasson led the scoring attack for the Jays with 26, and
Jedan Phillips dropped 21.
The Jays go away this Saturday
to Widener, and come back home
Monday to play Ursinus at 8 p.m.
Wednesday night the Blue Jays
play their final home game this
season against Haverford at 8
p.m.

Hustling Jays Cover Spread
by Patrick Furey
Last November 24, the JV
basketball team travelled to Cecil
Community College for their
season opener. For many of the
players on the team, it was not
only the first game of the season,
it was the first organized basketball game they had ever played
in. Most of the Blue Jays didn't
know what to expect, and those
who did expected the worst.
Well, that's exactly what they
got, as Cecil slam-dunked their
way to a 107-37 victory. That's
right, Hopkins was defeated by
70 points.
The best part about losing your
opener by 70 is that things can only get better. Gradually, the Blue
Jays improved to the point where
they were competetive in just
about every game they played. A
mere two weeks after losing to
Cecil, Hopkins came within four
points of their first victory in two
years. The very next day, they
came even closer, dropping to
Penn State (Ogontz) by a score of
56-54. Despite this drastic turnaround, all they had to show for
their efforts on January 26 was an
0-6 record.
Finally, the Blue Jays shook the
monkey off of their backs on
January 27, as they defeated
Messiah. After that, Hopkins
demonstrated their improvement
by extremely tough playing in
losses to Navy and Howard Community College. By last Monday,
the JV team had shown that they
could play solid basketball. They
had proven to their coach and to
their "faithful few" fans that
what they lacked in talent, they
made up for with guts and hustle. They could finally walk away
from their season with a feeling
of great accomplishment, for they
had regained the pride that they
had lost on November 24. It
would seem that Hopkins had
nothing left to prove as they
entered their final game of the
season last Monday at Homewood. Their opponent, however,
was Cecil Community College.
Cecil once again dominated
with their quickness, using a fullcourt press and a great inside

game to crush the Jays 87-37. But
this game wasn't the same as the
November 24 thrashing. There
were no slam dunks, no three-onone breakaways, and no chuckles
from the Cecil bench. Though
Hopkins lost by 50, they walked
away with a victory. They outhustled the Seahawks, and made
Cecil work for every basket. The
Blue Jays showed more guts.
It's difficult to single out individuals for outstanding improvement, because everyone on
the team has come a long way.
Freshman Tim Coyle has become
a good inside player, grabbing rebounds with authority and drawing fouls in key situations. Brian
"Sheep" Tarver has coupled an
outstanding shot with great hustle.
Steve Blumenthal has become a
consistent scoring machine, rack-

ing up three-pointers with ease.
Mike Stern has developed into
one of the finest rebounders on
the team, simply by consistently
muscling himself into the "smart
spot."
It's no secret that most of the
JV team played their final game
in a Hopkins basketball uniform
last Monday night, because next
season will probably see a drastic
change in the quality of Hopkins
hoops. Coach Web Johnson did
a tremendous job molding the
Blue Jays into a competitive unit.
His team may not be the most
talented in the world, but you'd
hae to look pretty hard to find a
team with more guts than the
Hopkins JV basketball team.
They've come a long way since
November 24.
